text: These are the wise sayings of Solomon, son of David, king of Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text: They show you how to know wisdom and teaching, to find the words of understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: They help you learn about the ways of wisdom and what is right and fair.
speaker: Narrator

text: They give wisdom to the child-like, and much learning and wisdom to those who are young.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise man will hear and grow in learning. A man of understanding will become able
speaker: Narrator

text: to understand a saying and a picture-story, the words of the wise and what they mean.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of much learning. Fools hate wisdom and teaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear your father’s teaching, my son, and do not turn away from your mother’s teaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they are a glory to your head and a chain of beauty around your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, if sinners try to lead you into sin, do not go with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they say, “Come with us. Let us lie in wait to kill someone. Let us set a trap for those who are without blame.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us swallow them alive like death, as those who go down to the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will find all kinds of things of great worth. We will fill our houses with the stolen riches.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throw in your share with us. We will all have one money bag.”
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, do not walk in the way with them. Keep your feet from their path.
speaker: Narrator

text: For their feet run to sin and hurry to kill.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, the net is spread for nothing if the bird is watching.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set traps for their own lives and wait to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Such are the ways of all who get things by hurting others. Their desire for stolen riches takes away their own lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wisdom calls out in the street. She lifts her voice in the center of town.
speaker: Narrator

text: There she cries out in the noisy streets. At the open gates of the city she speaks:
speaker: Narrator

text: “O foolish ones, how long will you love being foolish? How long will those who laugh at others be happy in their laughing? How long will fools hate much learning?
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen to my strong words! See, I will pour out my spirit on you. I will make my words known to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I called but you would not listen. I put out my hand and no one gave it a thought.
speaker: Narrator

text: You did not listen when I told you what you should do, and you would not hear any of my strong words.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I will laugh at your trouble. I will laugh when you are afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear will come to you like a storm. Hard times will come like a strong wind. When trouble and suffering come upon you,
speaker: Narrator

text: then they will call on me, but I will not answer. They will look for me, but they will not find me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because they hated much learning, and did not choose the fear of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They would not listen when I told them what they should do. They laughed at all my strong words.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they will eat the fruit of their own way, and be filled with their own plans.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the foolish will be killed by their turning away. The trust that fools put in themselves will destroy them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he who listens to me will live free from danger, and he will rest easy from the fear of what is sinful.”
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, if you receive my sayings and store up my teachings within you,
speaker: Narrator

text: make your ear open to wisdom. Turn your heart to understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you cry out to know right from wrong, and lift your voice for understanding;
speaker: Narrator

text: if you look for her as silver, and look for her as hidden riches;
speaker: Narrator

text: then you will understand the fear of the Lord, and find what is known of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord gives wisdom. Much learning and understanding come from His mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stores up perfect wisdom for those who are right with Him. He is a safe-covering to those who are right in their walk.
speaker: Narrator

text: He watches over the right way, and He keeps safe the way of those who belong to Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will understand what is right and good, and right from wrong, and you will know what you should do.
speaker: Narrator

text: For wisdom will come into your heart. And much learning will be pleasing to your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Good thinking will keep you safe. Understanding will watch over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be kept from the sinful man, and from the man who causes much trouble by what he says.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be kept from the man who leaves the right way to walk in the ways of darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text: from the one who is happy doing wrong, and who finds joy in the way of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: His ways are not straight and are not good.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be saved from the strange woman, from the sinful woman with her smooth words.
speaker: Narrator

text: She leaves the husband she had when she was young, and forgets the agreement with her God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For her house goes down to death, and her steps lead to the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: None who go to her return again, and they do not find the paths of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: So may you walk in the way of good men, and keep to the paths of those who are right and good.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those who are right with God will live in the land. The men without blame will stay in it,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the sinful will be destroyed from the land, and those who are not faithful will be taken away from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, do not forget my teaching. Let your heart keep my words.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they will add to you many days and years of life and peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let kindness and truth leave you. Tie them around your neck. Write them upon your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you will find favor and good understanding in the eyes of God and man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Trust in the Lord with all your heart, and do not trust in your own understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: Agree with Him in all your ways, and He will make your paths straight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be wise in your own eyes. Fear the Lord and turn away from what is sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be healing to your body and medicine to your bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Honor the Lord with your riches, and with the first of all you grow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then your store-houses will be filled with many good things and your barrels will flow over with new wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, listen when the Lord punishes you. Do not give up when He tells you what you must do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord punishes everyone He loves. He whips every son He receives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Happy is the man who finds wisdom, and the man who gets understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is better than getting silver and fine gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: She is worth more than stones of great worth. Nothing you can wish for compares with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Long life is in her right hand. Riches and honor are in her left hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her ways are pleasing, and all her paths are peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: She is a tree of life to those who take hold of her. Happy are all who hold her near.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord built the earth by wisdom. He built the heavens by understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: By what He knows, the seas were broken up and water falls from the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, do not allow them to leave your eyes. Keep perfect wisdom and careful thinking.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they will be life to your soul and a chain of beauty to your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will be safe as you walk on your way, and your foot will not trip.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will not be afraid when you lie down. When you lie down, your sleep will be sweet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be afraid of fear that comes all at once. And do not be afraid of the storm of the sinful when it comes.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord will be your trust. He will keep your foot from being caught.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not keep good from those who should have it, when it is in your power to do it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not say to your neighbor, “Go, and return tomorrow, and I will give it,” when you have it with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not plan for your neighbor to be hurt, while he trusts you enough to live beside you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not fight with a man for no reason, when he has done you no wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be jealous of a man who hurts others, and do not choose any of his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the bad man is hated by the Lord, but He is near to those who are right with Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The punishment of the Lord is on the house of the sinful, but He makes good come to the house of those who are right with Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: God makes fun of those who make fun of the truth but gives loving-favor to those who have no pride.
speaker: Narrator

text: Honor will be given to the wise, but shame will be given to fools.
speaker: Narrator

text: O sons, hear the teaching of a father. Listen so you may get understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I give you good teaching. Do not turn away from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I was a much loved and only son of my mother and father,
speaker: Narrator

text: he taught me, saying, “Hold my words close to your heart. Keep my teachings and live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get wisdom and understanding. Do not forget or turn away from the words of my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not leave her alone, and she will keep you safe. Love her, and she will watch over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The beginning of wisdom is: Get wisdom! And with all you have gotten, get understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: Honor her and she will honor you. She will honor you if you hold her to your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: She will put on your head a crown of loving-favor and beauty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear, my son, and receive my sayings, and the years of your life will be many.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have taught you in the way of wisdom. I have led you on the right paths.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you walk, your steps will not be stopped. If you run, you will not trip.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take hold of teaching. Do not let go. Watch over her, for she is your life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not go on the path of the sinful. Do not walk in the way of bad men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay away from it. Do not pass by it. Turn from it, and pass on.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they cannot sleep unless they do wrong. They are robbed of sleep unless they make someone fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they eat the bread of sin, and drink the wine of wrong-doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the way of those who are right is like the early morning light. It shines brighter and brighter until the perfect day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The way of the sinful is like darkness. They do not know what they trip over.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, listen to my words. Turn your ear to my sayings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let them leave your eyes. Keep them in the center of your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they are life to those who find them, and healing to their whole body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep your heart pure for out of it are the important things of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put false speaking away from you. Put bad talk far from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let your eyes look straight in front of you, and keep looking at what is in front of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Watch the path of your feet, and all your ways will be sure.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not turn to the right or to the left. Turn your foot away from sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, listen to my wisdom. Turn your ear to my understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you may know what is good thinking, and your lips may keep much learning.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the lips of a strange woman are as sweet as honey. Her talk is as smooth as oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the end she is as bitter tasting as wormwood, and as sharp as a sword that cuts both ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her feet go down to death. Her steps take hold of hell.
speaker: Narrator

text: She does not think about the path of life. Her ways go this way and that, and she does not know it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, my sons, listen to me. Do not turn away from the words of my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep far away from her. Do not go near the door of her house.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do, you would give your strength to others, and your years to those without loving-kindness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Strangers would be filled with your strength, and the fruits of your work would go to a strange house.
speaker: Narrator

text: You would cry inside yourself when your end comes, when your flesh and body are wasted away.
speaker: Narrator

text: You would say, “How I have hated teaching! My heart hated strong words!
speaker: Narrator

text: I have not listened to the voice of my teachers. I have not turned my ear to those who would teach me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I have a bad name in the meeting place of the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Drink water from your own pool, flowing water from your own well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Should the waters from your well flow away, rivers of water in the streets?
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them be yours alone, and not for strangers with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let your well be honored, and be happy with the wife you married when you were young.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let her be like a loving, female deer. Let her breasts please you at all times. Be filled with great joy always because of her love.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, why should you be carried away with a sinful woman and fall into the arms of a strange woman?
speaker: Narrator

text: For the ways of a man are seen by the eyes of the Lord, and He watches all his paths.
speaker: Narrator

text: His own sins will trap the sinful. He will be held with the ropes of his sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will die for want of teaching, and will go the wrong way because of the greatness of his foolish ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, if you have put yourself as a trust for what your neighbor owes to another, or if you have made a promise for a stranger,
speaker: Narrator

text: you have been trapped with the words of your lips. You have been caught with the words of your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this now, my son, and get yourself out of trouble, for you have come into the hand of your neighbor. Go without pride and beg your neighbor to let you go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let your eyes sleep. Do not let your eyes close.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take yourself away like a deer from the man who kills animals, and like a bird from the hand of the man who catches birds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to the ant, O lazy person. Watch and think about her ways, and be wise.
speaker: Narrator

text: She has no leader, head or ruler,
speaker: Narrator

text: but she gets her food ready in the summer, and gathers her food at the right time.
speaker: Narrator

text: How long will you lie down, O lazy person? When will you rise up from your sleep?
speaker: Narrator

text: A little sleep, a little rest, a little folding of the hands to rest,
speaker: Narrator

text: and being poor will come upon you like a robber, and your need like a man ready to fight.
speaker: Narrator

text: A person of no worth, a sinful man, is he who goes about telling lies.
speaker: Narrator

text: He winks with his eyes, makes signs with his feet, and makes certain moves with his fingers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He always plans to do sinful things because of his sinful heart. He causes arguing among people.
speaker: Narrator

text: So trouble will come upon him all at once. Right then he will be broken, and there will be no healing.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are six things which the Lord hates, yes, seven that are hated by Him:
speaker: Narrator

text: A proud look, a lying tongue, and hands that kill those who are without guilt,
speaker: Narrator

text: a heart that makes sinful plans, feet that run fast to sin,
speaker: Narrator

text: a person who tells lies about someone else, and one who starts fights among brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, keep the teaching of your father, and do not turn away from the teaching of your mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hold them always to your heart. Tie them around your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will lead you when you walk. They will watch over you when you sleep, and they will talk with you when you wake up.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the word is a lamp. The teaching is a light, and strong words that punish are the way of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: They keep you from the sinful woman, from the smooth tongue of a sinful woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not desire her beauty in your heart. Do not let her catch you with her eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: For because of a woman who sells the use of her body, one is brought down to a loaf of bread. A sinful woman hunts to take a man’s very life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Can a man carry fire in his arms, and his clothes not be burned?
speaker: Narrator

text: Can a man walk on hot coals, and his feet not be burned?
speaker: Narrator

text: So is he who goes in to his neighbor’s wife. Whoever touches her will be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Men do not hate a robber who steals food for himself when he is hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he is caught, he must pay seven times what he took. He must give up all the things in his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who does sex sins with a woman does not think well. He who does it is destroying himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will be hurt and ashamed, and his shame will not be taken away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jealousy makes a man angry. He will show no pity for the wrong that was done to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will not take pay, and he will not be happy even if you give him many gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, keep my words, and hold together my teachings within you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep my words and live. Keep my teachings as you would your own eye.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tie them upon your fingers. Write them upon your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to wisdom, “You are my sister.” Call understanding your special friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will keep you from the strange woman, from the stranger with her smooth words.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I looked out through the wood-work at the window of my house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I saw among the child-like and among the young people a young man without wisdom and understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: He passed through the street near her corner and took the path to her house,
speaker: Narrator

text: in the light of the evening, after it was dark.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, a woman comes to meet him. She is dressed like a woman who sells the use of her body, and with a heart that wants to fool and trap someone.
speaker: Narrator

text: She is loud and has a strong self-will. Her feet do not stay at home.
speaker: Narrator

text: She is now in the street, now in the center of town where people gather. She lies in wait at every corner.
speaker: Narrator

text: So she catches him and kisses him. With a hard face she says to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “It was time for me to give gifts on the altar in worship, and today I have paid what I promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I have come out to meet you, to look for you, and I have found you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have spread my bed with coverings of linen cloth from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have perfumed my bed with fine perfumes and spices.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let us take our fill of love until morning. Let us make ourselves happy with love.
speaker: Narrator

text: For my husband is not at home. He has gone on a long trip.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has taken a bag of money with him, and he will come home at full moon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She leads him away with her tempting talk. She tempts him with the smooth words of her lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: All at once he follows her, like a bull going to be killed, like a wild animal goes into a trap,
speaker: Narrator

text: until an arrow cuts through him. Like a bird that hurries into the net, he does not know that he will lose his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, my sons, listen to me. Listen to the words of my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let your heart turn aside to her ways. Do not turn aside into her paths.
speaker: Narrator

text: For she has hurt many and destroyed many others. She has killed a great number.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her house is the way to hell, going down to the rooms of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Does not wisdom call? Does not understanding raise her voice?
speaker: Narrator

text: She takes her stand on the top of the hill beside the way, where the paths meet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beside the gates in front of the town, at the open doors, she cries out,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I call to you, O men. My voice is to the sons of men.
speaker: Narrator

text: O child-like ones, learn to use wisdom. O fools, make your mind understand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen, for I will speak great things. What is right will come from my lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: For my mouth will speak the truth. My lips hate wrong-doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the words of my mouth are right and good. There is nothing in them that is against the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are all clear to him who understands, and right to those who find much learning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take my teaching instead of silver. Take much learning instead of fine gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: For wisdom is better than stones of great worth. All that you may desire cannot compare with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I, wisdom, live with understanding, and I find much learning and careful thinking.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fear of the Lord is to hate what is sinful. I hate pride, self-love, the way of sin, and lies.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have teaching and wisdom. I have understanding and power.
speaker: Narrator

text: By me kings rule and rulers make laws that are fair.
speaker: Narrator

text: By me rulers rule, and all the princes rule on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: I love those who love me, and those who look for me with much desire will find me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Riches and honor are mine, lasting riches and being right with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: My fruit is better than gold, even pure gold. What I give is better than fine silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: I walk in the way that is right with God, in the center of the ways that are fair.
speaker: Narrator

text: I give riches to those who love me, and fill their store-houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord made me at the beginning of His work, before His first works long ago.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was set apart long ago, from the beginning, before the earth was.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was born when there were no seas, when there were no pools full of water.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was born before the mountains and hills were in their places.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was before He had made the earth or the fields, or the first dust of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was there when He made the heavens, and when He drew a mark around the top of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was there when He put the skies above, and when He put the wells of the waters in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was there when He marked out the places for the sea, so that the waters would not go farther than what He said. I was there when He marked out the ground for the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was beside Him as the leading workman. I was His joy every day. I was always happy when I was near Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was happy in the world, His earth, and found joy in the sons of men.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So now, O sons, listen to me, for happy are they who keep my ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear my teaching and be wise. Do not turn away from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Happy is the man who listens to me, watching every day at my gates, waiting beside my doors.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he who finds me finds life, and gets favor from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he who misses me hurts himself. All those who hate me love death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Wisdom has built her house. She has made seven pillars to hold it up.
speaker: Narrator

text: She has cooked her food, and has mixed her wine, and she has set her table.
speaker: Narrator

text: She has sent out the young women who work for her. She calls from the highest places of the city,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever is easy to fool, let him turn in here!” She says to the one without understanding,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Come and eat my food, and drink the wine I have mixed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn from your foolish way, and live. Walk in the way of understanding.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He who speaks strong words to the man who laughs at the truth brings shame upon himself. He who speaks strong words to a sinful man gets hurt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not speak strong words to a man who laughs at the truth, or he will hate you. Speak strong words to a wise man, and he will love you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give teaching to a wise man and he will be even wiser. Teach a man who is right and good, and he will grow in learning.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom. To learn about the Holy One is understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by me your days will grow in number, and years will be added to your life.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you are wise, your wisdom is a help to you. If you laugh at the truth, you alone will suffer for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: A foolish woman makes much noise. She is open to sin, and knows nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: She sits at the door of her house or on a seat in the high places of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: She calls to those who pass by and are making their paths straight,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever is easy to fool, let him turn in here!” She says to the one without understanding,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Stolen water is sweet. And bread eaten in secret is pleasing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he does not know that the dead are there, and that the ones who visit her are in the bottom of hell.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sayings of Solomon:
A wise son makes a father glad, but a foolish son is a sorrow to his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Riches taken by wrong-doing do no good, but doing what is right and good saves from death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will not let those who are right with Him go hungry, but He puts to one side the desire of the sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who works with a lazy hand is poor, but the hand of the hard worker brings riches.
speaker: Narrator

text: A son who gathers in summer is wise, but a son who sleeps during gathering time brings shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: Good things are given to those who are right with God, but the mouth of the sinful hides trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are right with God are remembered with honor, but the name of the sinful will waste away.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wise in heart will receive teaching, but a fast talking fool will become nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who is right in his walk is sure in his steps, but he who takes the wrong way will be found out.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who winks the eye causes trouble, and a fast talking fool will become nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: The mouth of the one who is right with God is a well of life, but the mouth of the sinful hides trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hate starts fights, but love covers all sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wisdom is found on the lips of him who has understanding, but a stick is for the back of him who has no understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wise men store up learning, but the foolish will be destroyed with their mouths.
speaker: Narrator

text: The riches of a rich man are his strength, but the need of the poor is what destroys them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pay earned by those who are right with God is life, but the sinful are paid by being punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who listens to teaching is on the path of life, but he who will not listen to strong words goes the wrong way.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who hides hate has lying lips, and he who talks to hurt people is a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who talks much will for sure sin, but he who is careful what he says is wise.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tongue of those who are right with God is like fine silver, but the heart of the sinful is not worth much.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lips of those who are right with God feed many, but fools die for want of understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: The good that comes from the Lord makes one rich, and He adds no sorrow to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Doing wrong is like play to a fool, but a man of understanding has wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: What the sinful man is afraid of will come upon him, and what is wanted by the man who is right with God will be given to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the storm passes, the sinful man is no more, but the man who is right with God has a place to stand forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like sour wine to the teeth and smoke to the eyes, so is the lazy one to those who send him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fear of the Lord makes life longer, but the years of the sinful will be cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hope of those who are right with God is joy, but the hope of the sinful comes to nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: The way of the Lord is a strong-place to those who are faithful, but it destroys those who do wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are right with God will never be shaken, but the sinful will not live in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The mouth of those who are right with God flows with wisdom, but the sinful tongue will be stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lips of those who are right with God speak what is pleasing to others, but the mouth of the sinful speaks only what is bad.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hates a false weight, but a true weight is His joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: When pride comes, then comes shame, but wisdom is with those who have no pride.
speaker: Narrator

text: The honor of good people will lead them, but those who hurt others will be destroyed by their own false ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Riches are of no use in the day of God’s anger, but being right with God saves from death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those right with God, who are without blame, make a straight way for themselves, but the sinful will fall by their own wrong-doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Being right with God will save the honest man, but those who hurt others will be trapped by their wrong desires.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a sinful man dies, his hope dies with him, and all his power comes to nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who is right with God is kept from trouble, but the sinful get into trouble instead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sinful man destroys his neighbor with his mouth, but those who are fair will be saved through knowing God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The city is glad when everything goes well with those who are right with God, and there are shouts of joy when the sinful are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: A city is honored by the good things that come to the faithful, but it is torn down by the mouth of the sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who hates his neighbor does not think well, but a man of understanding keeps quiet.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who is always telling stories makes secrets known, but he who can be trusted keeps a thing hidden.
speaker: Narrator

text: A nation falls where there is no wise leading, but it is safe where there are many wise men who know what to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who puts himself as trust for what a stranger owes to another will suffer for it, but he who hates to be trusted for what another owes is safe.
speaker: Narrator

text: A kind woman gets honor, and bad men get riches.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who shows loving-kindness does himself good, but the man without pity hurts himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sinful man earns false pay, but he who spreads what is right and good gets pay that is sure.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who will not be moved from being right with God will live, but he who goes for what is bad will bring about his own death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hates those who are sinful in heart, but those who walk without blame are His joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know for sure that the sinful man will not go without being punished, but the children of those who are right with God will be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: A beautiful woman who does not think well is like a gold ring in the nose of a pig.
speaker: Narrator

text: The desire of those who are right with God is only good, but the hope of the sinful is anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is one who is free in giving, and yet he grows richer. And there is one who keeps what he should give, but he ends up needing more.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who gives much will have much, and he who helps others will be helped himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people curse him who keeps grain for himself, but good comes to him who sells it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who looks for good finds favor, but he who looks for wrong-doing will have bad come to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who trusts in his riches will fall, but those who are right with God will grow like a green leaf.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who troubles his own house will be given the wind, and the foolish will serve those with a wise heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fruit of those who are right with God is a tree of life, and he who wins souls is wise.
speaker: Narrator

text: If those who are right with God will be paid on earth, how much more the sinful and the wrong-doer!
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever loves strong teaching loves much learning, but he who hates strong words is foolish.
speaker: Narrator

text: A good man will get favor from the Lord, but He will punish a man who makes sinful plans.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man will not stand by doing what is wrong, but the root of those who are right with God will not be moved.
speaker: Narrator

text: A good wife is the pride and joy of her husband, but she who brings shame is like cancer to his bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: The thoughts of those who are right with God can be trusted, but the words of the sinful are false.
speaker: Narrator

text: The words of the sinful lie in wait for blood, but the mouth of the faithful will take them away from trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sinful are destroyed and are no more, but the house of those who are right with God will stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man will be praised for his wisdom, but a man with a sinful mind will be hated.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who has only a little honor and has a servant is better than one who honors himself and does not have bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who is right with God cares for his animal, but the sinful man is hard and has no pity.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who works his land will have all the bread he needs, but he who follows what is of no worth has no wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sinful man wants what sinful men have, but the root of those who are right with God gives fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: A sinful man is trapped by the sin of his lips, but those who are right with God will get away from trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man will be filled with good from the fruit of his words, and the work of a man’s hands will return to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The way of a fool is right in his own eyes, but a wise man listens to good teaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: The anger of a fool is known at once, but a wise man does not speak when he is spoken against.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who speaks the truth tells what is right, but a liar tells lies.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is one whose foolish words cut like a sword, but the tongue of the wise brings healing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lips that tell the truth will last forever, but a lying tongue lasts only for a little while.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lying is in the heart of those who plan what is bad, but those who plan peace have joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: No trouble comes upon those who are right with God, but the sinful are filled with trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hates lying lips, but those who speak the truth are His joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise man hides how much learning he has, but the heart of fools makes known their foolish way.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hand of those who do their best will rule, but the lazy hand will be made to work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Worry in the heart of a man weighs it down, but a good word makes it glad.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who is right with God is a teacher to his neighbor, but the way of the sinful leads them the wrong way.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lazy man will not cook the food he has caught, but the man who does his best has what is of great worth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Life is in the way of those who are right with God, and in its path there is no death.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise son listens when his father tells him the right way, but one who laughs at the truth does not listen when strong words are spoken to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who is careful what he says will have good come to him, but the one who wants to hurt others will have trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who watches over his mouth keeps his life. He who opens his lips wide will be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The soul of the lazy person has strong desires but gets nothing, but the soul of the one who does his best gets more than he needs.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who is right with God hates lies, but the actions of a sinful man are hated and he is put to shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: What is right and good watches over the one whose way is without blame, but sin destroys the sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is one who pretends to be rich, but has nothing. Another pretends to be poor, but has many riches.
speaker: Narrator

text: A rich man can use his riches to save his life, but the poor man does not hear strong words spoken to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are right with God are full of light, but the lamp of the sinful will be put out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fighting comes only from pride, but wisdom is with those who listen when told what they should do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Riches taken by false ways become less and less, but riches grow for the one who gathers by hard work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hope that is put off makes the heart sick, but a desire that comes into being is a tree of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who hates the Word is under its power, but he who fears the Word will be well paid.
speaker: Narrator

text: The teaching of the wise is a well of life, to save one from the nets of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Good understanding wins favor, but the way of the sinful is hard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every wise man acts with much learning, but a fool makes his foolish way known.
speaker: Narrator

text: A sinful helper falls into trouble, but a faithful helper brings healing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who will not listen to strong teaching will become poor and ashamed, but he who listens when strong words are spoken will be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: A desire that is filled is sweet to the soul, but fools hate to give up what is sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who walks with wise men will be wise, but the one who walks with fools will be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Trouble follows sinners, but good things will be given to those who are right with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: A good man leaves what he owns for his children’s children. The riches of the sinner are stored up for those who are right with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Much food is in the plowed land of the poor, but it is taken away because of wrong-doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who does not punish his son when he needs it hates him, but he who loves him will punish him when he needs it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who is right with God has all the food he needs, but the stomach of the sinful man never has enough.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wise woman builds her house, but the foolish woman tears it down with her own hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who walks in honor fears the Lord, but he who is sinful in his ways hates Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: A foolish man’s talk brings a stick to his back, but the lips of the wise will keep them safe.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is no grain where there are no oxen, but much grain comes by the strength of the ox.
speaker: Narrator

text: A faithful man who tells what he knows will not lie, but the man who is not faithful will lie.
speaker: Narrator

text: One who laughs at the truth looks for wisdom and does not find it, but much learning is easy to him who has understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go away from a foolish man, for you will not find words of much learning.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wisdom of the wise man is to understand what to do, but lying is the foolish way of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fools laugh at sin, but the favor of God is among the faithful.
speaker: Narrator

text: The heart knows when it is bitter, and a stranger cannot share its joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The house of the sinful will be destroyed, but all will go well in the tent of the faithful.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a way which looks right to a man, but its end is the way of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even while laughing the heart may be in pain, and the end of joy may be sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who has gone back into sin will get the fruit of his ways, and a good man will get the fruit of what he does.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who is easy to fool believes everything, but the wise man looks where he goes.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise man fears God and turns away from what is sinful, but a fool is full of pride and is not careful.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who has a quick temper acts in a foolish way, and a man who makes sinful plans is hated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are easy to fool are foolish, but the wise have much learning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sinful men will bow in front of the good, and at the gates of those who are right with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poor man is hated even by his neighbor, but the rich man has many friends.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who hates his neighbor sins, but happy is he who shows loving-favor to the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not those who make sinful plans go the wrong way? Kindness and truth are for those who plan good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some good comes from all work. Nothing but talk leads only to being poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: What the wise receive is their riches, but fools are known by their foolish ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: A faithful man who tells what he knows saves lives, but he who tells lies hurts others.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is strong trust in the fear of the Lord, and His children will have a safe place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fear of the Lord is a well of life. Its waters keep a man from death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The shining-greatness of a king is in many people, but without people a prince has nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who is slow to get angry has great understanding, but he who has a quick temper makes his foolish way look right.
speaker: Narrator

text: A heart that has peace is life to the body, but wrong desires are like the wasting away of the bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who makes it hard for the poor brings shame to his Maker, but he who shows loving-favor to those in need honors Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sinful is thrown down by his wrong-doing, but the man who is right with God has a safe place when he dies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wisdom rests in the heart of one who has understanding, but what is in the heart of fools is made known.
speaker: Narrator

text: Being right with God makes a nation great, but sin is a shame to any people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king’s favor is toward a wise servant, but his anger is toward the one who brings shame by what he does.
speaker: Narrator

text: A gentle answer turns away anger, but a sharp word causes anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tongue of the wise uses much learning in a good way, but the mouth of fools speaks in a foolish way.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eyes of the Lord are in every place, watching the bad and the good.
speaker: Narrator

text: A gentle tongue is a tree of life, but a sinful tongue crushes the spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: A fool turns away from the strong teaching of his father, but he who remembers the strong words spoken to him is wise.
speaker: Narrator

text: Great riches are in the house of those who are right with God, but trouble is what the sinful will receive.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lips of the wise spread much learning, but the minds of fools do not.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hates the gifts of the sinful, but the prayer of the faithful is His joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hates the way of the sinful, but He loves him who follows what is right and good.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who turns from the right way will be punished. He who hates strong words spoken to him will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: The world of the dead lies open before the Lord. How much more the hearts of men!
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who laughs at the truth has no love for the one who speaks strong words to him. He will not go to the wise.
speaker: Narrator

text: A glad heart makes a happy face, but when the heart is sad, the spirit is broken.
speaker: Narrator

text: The mind of him who has understanding looks for much learning, but the mouth of fools feeds on foolish ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the days of the suffering are hard, but a glad heart has a special supper all the time.
speaker: Narrator

text: A little with the fear of the Lord is better than great riches with trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: A dish of vegetables with love is better than eating the best meat with hate.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man with a bad temper starts fights, but he who is slow to anger quiets fighting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The path of the lazy man is grown over with thorns, but the path of the faithful is a good road.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise son makes a father glad, but a foolish man hates his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: A foolish way is joy to him who has no wisdom, but a man of understanding walks straight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Plans go wrong without talking together, but they will go well when many wise men talk about what to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: To give a good answer is a joy to a man, and how pleasing is a word given at the right time!
speaker: Narrator

text: The path of life leads up for the wise, so he may keep away from hell below.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will tear down the house of the proud, but He will make a place for the woman whose husband has died.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hates the plans of the sinful, but the words of the pure are pleasing to Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who gets things by doing wrong brings trouble to his family, but he who will not be paid in secret for wrong-doing will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: The mind of the one who is right with God thinks about how to answer, but the mouth of the sinful pours out sinful things.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord is far from the sinful, but He hears the prayer of those who are right with Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The light of the eyes makes the heart glad. Good news puts fat on the bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: He whose ear listens to careful words spoken will live among the wise.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who does not listen to strong teaching hates himself, but he who listens when strong words are spoken gets understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fear of the Lord is the teaching for wisdom, and having no pride comes before honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The plans of the heart belong to man, but the answer of the tongue is from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the ways of a man are pure in his own eyes, but the Lord weighs the thoughts of the heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Trust your work to the Lord, and your plans will work out well.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has made all things for His own plans, even the sinful for the day of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who is proud in heart is a shame to the Lord. For sure, that one will be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sin has been paid for by loving-kindness and truth. The fear of the Lord keeps one away from sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the ways of a man are pleasing to the Lord, He makes even those who hate him to be at peace with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: A little earned in a right way is better than much earned in a wrong way.
speaker: Narrator

text: The mind of a man plans his way, but the Lord shows him what to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lips of the king should decide as God would. His mouth should not sin in deciding what is right or wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: What is fair in telling the weight of something belongs to the Lord. He cares about all the weights of the bag.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a hated thing for kings to do what is wrong. For a throne is built on what is right.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lips that speak what is right and good are the joy of kings, and he who speaks the truth is loved.
speaker: Narrator

text: The anger of a king carries death, but a wise man will quiet it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Life is in the light of a king’s face, and his favor is like a cloud bringing the spring rain.
speaker: Narrator

text: To get wisdom is much better than getting gold. To get understanding should be chosen instead of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: The road of the faithful turns away from sin. He who watches his way keeps his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pride comes before being destroyed and a proud spirit comes before a fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is better to be poor in spirit among poor people, than to divide the riches that were taken with the proud.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who listens to the Word will find good, and happy is he who trusts in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wise in heart will be called understanding. And to speak in a pleasing way helps people know what you say is right.
speaker: Narrator

text: Understanding is a well of life to him who has it, but to speak strong words to fools is of no use.
speaker: Narrator

text: The heart of the wise has power over his mouth and adds learning to his lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pleasing words are like honey. They are sweet to the soul and healing to the bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a way that looks right to a man, but its end is the way of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: A workman’s hunger works for him. The need of his mouth pushes him on.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man of no worth looks for wrong-doing. His words are like burning fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: A bad man spreads trouble. One who hurts people with bad talk separates good friends.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who hurts people tempts his neighbor to do the same, and leads him in a way that is not good.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who winks his eyes plans to do bad things. He who closes his lips allows sinful things to happen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hair that is turning white is like a crown of honor. It is found in the way of being right with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who is slow to anger is better than the powerful. And he who rules his spirit is better than he who takes a city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Man decides by throwing an object into the lap, but it is the Lord only who decides.
speaker: Narrator

text: A dry piece of food with peace and quiet is better than a house full of food with fighting.
speaker: Narrator

text: A servant who is wise in what he does will rule over a son who acts in shame. He will share in what is given as one of the brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The melting-pot is for silver and the hot fire is for gold, but the Lord tests hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wrong-doer listens to sinful lips. A liar listens to a tongue that destroys.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who laughs at the poor brings shame to his Maker. He who is glad at trouble will be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Grandchildren are the pride and joy of old men and a son is proud of his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fine speaking is not right for a fool. Even worse are lying lips to a ruler.
speaker: Narrator

text: Being paid in secret for wrong-doing is like a stone of much worth to the one who has it. Wherever he turns, he does well.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who covers a sin looks for love. He who tells of trouble separates good friends.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man of understanding learns more from being told the right thing to do than a fool learns from being beaten a hundred times.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who will not obey looks only for what is bad. So one who has no loving-pity will be sent against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man meeting a bear robbed of her little ones is better than meeting a fool in his foolish way.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man returns bad for good, trouble will not leave his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The beginning of trouble is like letting out water. So stop arguing before fighting breaks out.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who says that the sinful are right, and he who says those who do right are wrong, both are hated by the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: It does a fool no good to try to buy wisdom, when he has no understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: A friend loves at all times. A brother is born to share troubles.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man without good thinking makes promises, and becomes a trust for what another man owes his neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who loves sin loves making trouble. He who opens his door wide for trouble is looking for a way to be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who has a sinful heart finds no good. He who has a sinful tongue falls into sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: A foolish son is a sorrow to his father, and the father of a fool has no joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: A glad heart is good medicine, but a broken spirit dries up the bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: A sinful man receives pay in secret to change the right way into wrong-doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wisdom is with the one who has understanding, but the eyes of a fool are on the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: A foolish son is a sorrow to his father, and trouble to her who gave birth to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not good to punish those who are right with God, and it is wrong to beat men of honor for being faithful.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who is careful in what he says has much learning, and he who has a quiet spirit is a man of understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even a fool, when he keeps quiet, is thought to be wise. When he closes his lips, he is thought of as a man of understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who stays away from others cares only about himself. He argues against all good wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: A fool does not find joy in understanding, but only in letting his own mind be known.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a sinful man comes, hate comes also, and where there is no honor, there is shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: The words of a man’s mouth are deep waters. Wisdom comes like a flowing river making a pleasant noise.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not good to favor the sinful, or to keep what is fair from one who is right with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lips of a fool bring fighting, and his mouth calls for a beating.
speaker: Narrator

text: The mouth of a fool is what destroys him, and his lips are a trap to his soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: The words of one who speaks about others in secret are like tempting bites of food. They go down into the inside parts of the body.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who is lazy in his work is a brother to him who destroys.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the Lord is a strong tower. The man who does what is right runs into it and is safe.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rich man’s money is his strong city, and he thinks it is like a high wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: The heart of a man is proud before he is destroyed, but having no pride goes before honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: If one gives an answer before he hears, it makes him foolish and ashamed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The spirit of a man can help him through his sickness, but who can carry a broken spirit?
speaker: Narrator

text: An understanding mind gets much learning, and the ear of the wise listens for much learning.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man’s gift makes room for him, and brings him in front of great men.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who tells his story first makes people think he is right, until the other comes to test him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throwing an object to decide puts an end to arguing. It keeps powerful men from fighting.
speaker: Narrator

text: A brother who has been hurt in his spirit is harder to be won than a strong city, and arguing is like the iron gates of a king’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man’s stomach will be filled with the fruit of his mouth. He will be filled with what his lips speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: Death and life are in the power of the tongue, and those who love it will eat its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who finds a wife finds a good thing, and gets favor from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poor man asks for loving-kindness, but the rich man is hard in his answers.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who has friends must be a friend, but there is a friend who stays nearer than a brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: A poor man who walks with honor is better than a fool who is sinful in his speaking.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not good for a person to be without much learning, and he who hurries with his feet rushes into sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foolish acts of man make his way bad, and his heart is angry toward the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Riches add many friends, but a poor man is separated from his friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who tells lies about someone will be punished. He who tells lies will not get away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many will ask for the favor of a man who gives much, and every man is a friend to him who gives gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the brothers of a poor man hate him. How much more do his friends go far from him! He runs to them with words, but they are gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who gets wisdom loves his own soul. He who keeps understanding will find good.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who tells lies about someone will be punished. He who tells lies will be lost.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not right for a fool to live in great comfort, and for sure, for a servant to rule over rulers.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man’s understanding makes him slow to anger. It is to his honor to forgive and forget a wrong done to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king’s anger is like the noise of a lion, but his favor is like morning water upon the grass.
speaker: Narrator

text: A foolish son destroys his father. The arguing of a wife is like water falling drop by drop all the time.
speaker: Narrator

text: House and riches are handed down from fathers, but an understanding wife is from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Being lazy makes one go into a deep sleep, and a lazy man will suffer from being hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who keeps God’s Word keeps his soul, but he who is not careful of his ways will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who shows kindness to a poor man gives to the Lord and He will pay him in return for his good act.
speaker: Narrator

text: Punish your son if he needs it while there is hope, and do not worry about his crying.
speaker: Narrator

text: An angry man will suffer punishment. For if you save him from his trouble, you will only have to do it again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen to words about what you should do, and take your punishment if you need it, so that you may be wise the rest of your days.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are many plans in a man’s heart, but it is the Lord’s plan that will stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: What is desired in a man is his kindness, and it is better to be a poor man than a liar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fear of the Lord leads to life, and he who has it will sleep well, and will not be touched by sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lazy man buries his hand in the dish, and will not even bring it to his mouth again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hit a man who laughs at the truth, and the foolish may become wise. But speak strong words to one who has understanding, and he will get more learning.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who hurts his father and puts his mother out of the house is a son who causes much shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, stop listening to teaching that will cause you to turn away from the words of much learning.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man without worth who tells all he knows laughs at what is right and fair, and the mouth of the sinful spreads wrong-doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ways of punishing are made ready for those who laugh at the truth, and beatings are for the back of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wine makes people act in a foolish way. Strong drink starts fights. Whoever is fooled by it is not wise.
speaker: Narrator

text: The anger of a king is like the noise of a lion. He who makes him angry gives up his own life.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is an honor for a man to keep away from fighting, but any fool will argue.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lazy man does not plow before winter. So he begs during gathering time and has nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: The plan in a man’s heart is like water in a deep well, but a man of understanding gets it out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many men tell about their own loving-kindness and good ways but who can find a faithful man?
speaker: Narrator

text: How happy are the sons of a man who is right with God and walks in honor!
speaker: Narrator

text: A king who sits on his throne to judge finds out all sin with his eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who can say, “I have made my heart clean, and I am pure from my sin?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hates the use of tools that lie about how heavy or how long something is.
speaker: Narrator

text: A young man makes himself known by his actions and proves if his ways are pure and right.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hearing ear and the seeing eye were both made by the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not love sleep, or you will become poor. Open your eyes, and you will be filled with food.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It is bad, it is bad,” says the one who buys, but when he goes away, he talks much about his good buy.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is gold and many stones of great worth, but the lips of much learning are worth more.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take a man’s coat when he has given himself as trust for what a stranger owes. And hold him to his promise when he gives himself as trust for what the people from other lands owe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bread a man gets by lying is sweet to him, but later his mouth will be filled with sand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make plans by listening to what others have to say, and make war by listening to the leading of wise men.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who goes about talking to hurt people makes secrets known. So do not be with those who talk about others.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a son talks against his father or his mother, his lamp will be put out in the time of darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: A large gift received at one time in a hurry will not bring good in the end.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not say, “I will punish wrong-doing.” Wait on the Lord, and He will take care of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Giving the wrong weight is hated by the Lord. And weighing something wrong is not good.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man’s steps are decided by the Lord. How can anyone understand his own way?
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a trap for a man to say without thinking, “It is holy,” and then later think more about what he has promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise king puts the sinful aside and crushes the grain over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The spirit of man is the lamp of the Lord. It shows all the inside parts of his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: A king will stay in power as long as he is faithful and true. He can stay on his throne if he does what is right and good.
speaker: Narrator

text: The honor of young men is their strength. And the honor of old men is their hair turning white.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beatings that hurt clean away sin. And beatings make even the inside parts clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: The heart of the king is like rivers of water in the hand of the Lord. He turns it where He wishes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every man’s way is right in his own eyes, but the Lord knows the hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text: To do what is right and good and fair is more pleasing to the Lord than gifts given on the altar in worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eyes lifted high and a proud heart is sin and is the lamp of the sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: The plans of those who do their best lead only to having all they need, but all who are in a hurry come only to want.
speaker: Narrator

text: Getting riches by a lying tongue is like a passing cloud, and leads to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The way the sinful hurt others will draw them away, because they will not do what is right and fair.
speaker: Narrator

text: The way of a guilty man is sinful, but the actions of the pure man are right.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is better to live in a corner of a roof than in a house shared with an arguing woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: The soul of the sinful has a desire for what is bad. His neighbor finds no favor in his eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the man who laughs at the truth is punished, the fool becomes wise. When a wise man is taught, he gets much learning.
speaker: Narrator

text: The One Who is right and good thinks about the house of the sinful, and the sinful are thrown down to be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who shuts his ears to the cry of the poor will also cry himself and not be answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: A gift in secret quiets anger. A gift from the heart quiets strong anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: When what is right and fair is done, it is a joy for those who are right with God. But it fills the sinful with fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who goes away from the way of understanding will rest in the gathering of the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who loves only fun will become a poor man. He who loves wine and oil will not become rich.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sinful man is the price given for the man who is right with God, the man who is not faithful for the faithful man.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is better to live in a desert land than with a woman who argues and causes trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are riches and oil of great worth in the house of the wise, but a foolish man swallows them up.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who follows what is right and loving and kind finds life, right-standing with God and honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise man goes over the city walls of the powerful, and brings down the strong-place in which they trust.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who watches over his mouth and his tongue keeps his soul from troubles.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Proud,” “Self-important” and “One who laughs at the truth” are the names of the man who acts without respect and is proud.
speaker: Narrator

text: The desire of the lazy man kills him, for his hands will not work.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is filled with desire all day long, but the man who is right with God gives all he can.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gift given on an altar in worship by the sinful is a hated thing. How much more when he brings it for the wrong reason!
speaker: Narrator

text: A person who tells a lie about someone else will be lost, but the man who listens to the truth will speak forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: A sinful man’s face shows he is pretending, but a good man is sure of himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is no wisdom and no understanding and no words that can stand against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The horse is made ready for war, but winning the fight belongs to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: A good name is to be chosen instead of many riches. Favor is better than silver and gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rich and the poor meet together. The Lord is the maker of them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise man sees sin and hides himself, but the foolish go on, and are punished for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The reward for not having pride and having the fear of the Lord is riches, honor and life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thorns and traps are in the way of the sinful. He who watches himself will stay far from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring up a child by teaching him the way he should go, and when he is old he will not turn away from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rich rules over the poor. The man who uses something that belongs to someone else is ruled by the one who let him use it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who plants sin will gather trouble, and the heavy stick of his anger will break.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who gives much will be honored, for he gives some of his food to the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Send away the man who laughs at the truth, and arguing, fighting and shame will stop.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who loves a pure heart and is kind in his speaking has the king as his friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eyes of the Lord keep watch over much learning, but He destroys the words of the man who is not faithful.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lazy man says, “There is a lion outside! I will be killed in the streets!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The mouth of a sinful woman is a deep hole. He with whom the Lord is angry will fall into it.
speaker: Narrator

text: A foolish way is held in the heart of a child, but the punishing stick will send it far from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who makes it hard for the poor by getting more for himself, or who gives to the rich, will become poor himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn your ear and hear the words of the wise, and open your mind to what they teach.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it will be pleasing if you keep them in your heart, so they may be ready on your lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have taught you today, even you, so that your trust may be in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have I not written to you great things of wise teaching and much learning
speaker: Narrator

text: to show you that the words of truth are sure, so you may give a true answer to him who sent you?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not rob the poor because he is poor, or crush those who suffer at the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord will stand by them and help them, and take the life of those who rob them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not have anything to do with a man given to anger, or go with a man who has a bad temper.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or you might learn his ways and get yourself into a trap.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be among those who make promises and put themselves up as trust for what others owe.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you have nothing with which to pay, why should he take your bed from under you?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not take away the old land-mark which your fathers have set.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you see a man who is good at his work? He will stand in front of kings. He will not stand in front of men who are not important.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you sit down to eat with a ruler, think about what is in front of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put a knife to your neck if you are a man who is given to much eating.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not desire his special foods, for they are put there for no good reason.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not work hard to be rich. Stop trying to get things for yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you set your eyes upon it, it is gone. For sure, riches make themselves wings like an eagle that flies toward the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not eat the bread of a man who thinks only about himself. Do not have a desire for his fine food.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as he thinks in his heart, so is he. He says to you, “Eat and drink!” But his heart is not with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will spit up the piece of food you have eaten, and waste your good words.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not speak in the hearing of a fool, for he will hate the wisdom of your words.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not take away the old land-mark, or go into the fields of those without a father.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the One Who saves them is strong. He will stand by them and give them help against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Open your heart to teaching, and your ears to words of much learning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not keep from punishing the child if he needs it. If you beat him with the stick, he will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beat him with the stick, and save his soul from hell.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, if your heart is wise, my own heart will be glad also.
speaker: Narrator

text: My heart will be full of joy when your lips speak what is right.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let your heart be jealous of sinners, but live in the fear of the Lord always.
speaker: Narrator

text: For sure there is a future and your hope will not be cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen, my son, and be wise. Lead your heart in the way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be with those who drink too much wine or eat too much meat.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the man who drinks too much or eats too much will become poor, and much sleep will dress a man in torn clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen to your father who gave you life, and do not hate your mother when she is old.
speaker: Narrator

text: Buy truth, and do not sell it. Get wisdom and teaching and understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: The father of one who is right with God will have much joy. He who has a wise son will be glad in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let your father and mother be glad, and let her who gave birth to you be full of joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give me your heart, my son. Let your eyes find joy in my ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a woman who sells the use of her body is like a deep hole. A sinful woman is a narrow well.
speaker: Narrator

text: She lies in wait as a robber, and makes many more men not faithful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who has trouble? Who has sorrow? Who is fighting? Who is complaining? Who is hurt without a reason? Who has eyes that have become red?
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who stay a long time over wine. Those who go to taste mixed wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not look at wine when it is red, when it shines in the cup, when it is smooth in going down.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the end it bites like a snake. It stings like the bite of a snake with poison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your eyes will see strange things. Your mind will say the wrong things.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you will be like one who lies down in the center of the sea, or like one who lies above a ship’s sail.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They hit me, but I was not hurt. They beat me, but I did not know it. When will I wake up? I will look for another drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be jealous of sinful men. Do not want to be with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For their hearts make plans to hurt others and their lips talk about trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: A house is built by wisdom. It is made strong by understanding,
speaker: Narrator

text: and by much learning the rooms are filled with all riches that are pleasing and of great worth.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise man is strong. A man of much learning adds to his strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by wise leading you will make war, and the fight is won when there are many wise men to help you make the plans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wisdom is too hard for a fool to understand. He does not open his mouth in the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who plans to do wrong will be called a trouble maker.
speaker: Narrator

text: Planning to do foolish things is sin, and the man who laughs at the truth is hated by men.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you are weak in the day of trouble, your strength is small.
speaker: Narrator

text: Save those who are being taken away to death. Keep them from being killed.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you say, “See, we did not know this,” does not He Who knows what is in hearts see it? Does not He Who keeps watch over your soul know it? And will He not pay each man for his work?
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, eat honey, for it is good. Yes, the honey from the comb is sweet to your taste.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know that wisdom is like this to your soul. If you find it, there will be a future, and your hope will not be cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text: O sinful man, do not lie in wait against the house of the man who is right with God. Do not destroy his resting place.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a man who is right with God falls seven times, and rises again, but the sinful fall in time of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be full of joy when the one who hates you falls. Do not let your heart be glad when he trips.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will see it and will not be pleased, and He will turn away His anger from him.
speaker: Narrator
