text: Do not worry yourself because of those who do wrong, and do not be jealous of the sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: For there will be no future for the sinful man. The lamp of the sinful will be put out.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, fear the Lord and the king. Have nothing to do with those who are given to change.
speaker: Narrator

text: For their trouble will rise up all at once, and who knows how much both of them will destroy?
speaker: Narrator

text: These also are sayings of the wise. It is not good to show favor in judging.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who says to the sinful, “You are right and good,” will be spoken against by people and hated by nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: But those who speak strong words to the sinful will find joy and good will come upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text: To give the right answer is like a kiss on the lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get your work done outside. Make your fields ready. Then after that, build your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not speak against your neighbor without a reason, and do not lie with your lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not say, “I will do to him as he has done to me. I will pay the man for what he has done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I passed by the field of the lazy man, by the grape-vines of the man without understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: And see, it was all grown over with thorns. The ground was covered with weeds, and its stone wall was broken down.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I saw it, I thought about it. I looked and received teaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A little sleep, a little rest, a little folding of the hands to rest,”
speaker: Narrator

text: and your being poor will come as a robber, and your need like a man ready to fight.
speaker: Narrator

text: These also are wise sayings of Solomon, which were written down by the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is the greatness of God to keep things hidden, but it is the greatness of kings to find things out.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the heavens are high and the earth is deep, so the heart of kings is more than can be known.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take away the waste from the silver, and a silver pot comes out for the workman.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the sinful away from the king, and his throne will stand on what is right and good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not honor yourself in front of the king, and do not stand in the place of great men.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is better to be told, “Come up here,” than to be put down in front of the ruler whom your eyes have seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not go out in a hurry to argue. Or what will you do in the end, when your neighbor puts you to shame?
speaker: Narrator

text: Argue your side of the problem with your neighbor, but do not tell the secret of another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or he who hears you may put you to shame, and bad things will be said about you forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: A word spoken at the right time is like fruit of gold set in silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise man speaking strong words to a listening ear is like a piece of gold for the ear and a beautiful object of fine gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: A faithful man who carries news is like the cold of snow at gathering time to those who send him, for he makes the spirit of his owners feel new again.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who talks much of a gift he never gives is like clouds and wind without rain.
speaker: Narrator

text: When one is slow to anger, a ruler may be won over. A gentle tongue will break a bone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have you found honey? Eat only what you need, or you may become filled with it and spit it up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let your foot be in your neighbor’s house too much, or he may become tired of you and hate you.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who tells a lie against his neighbor is like a heavy stick or a sword or a sharp arrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: In time of trouble, trusting in a man who is not faithful is like a bad tooth or a foot out of joint.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who sings songs to a heavy heart is like one who takes off a coat on a cold day, or like sour wine poured on soda.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the one who hates you is hungry, feed him. If he is thirsty, give him water.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do that, you will be making him more ashamed of himself, and the Lord will reward you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The north wind brings rain, and a tongue that hurts people brings angry looks.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is better to live in a corner of the roof than in a house shared with an arguing woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: Good news from a land far away is like cold water to a tired soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who does what is right but gives way in front of the sinful, is like a well of mud or poisoned water.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not good to eat much honey, and looking for honor is not good.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who cannot rule his own spirit is like a city whose walls are broken down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like snow in summer and like rain at gathering time, so honor is not right for a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like a sparrow in its traveling, like a swallow in its flying, so bad words said against someone without reason do not come to rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: A whip is for the horse, leather ropes are for the donkey, and a stick is for the back of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not answer a fool by his foolish ways, or you will be like him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Answer a fool in the way he has earned by his foolish acts, so he will not be wise in his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who sends a letter by the hand of a fool cuts off his own feet and brings trouble upon himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise saying in the mouth of fools is like the legs on a man who cannot walk.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who gives honor to a fool is like one who ties a stone in a sling.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise saying in the mouth of fools is like a thorn that goes into the hand of a man who drinks too much.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who hires a fool or hires those who pass by is like a man who uses a bow to hurt everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: A fool who does his foolish act again is like a dog that turns back to what he has thrown up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you see a man who is wise in his own eyes? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lazy man says, “There is a lion in the way! There is a lion in the streets!”
speaker: Narrator

text: As a door turns, so does the lazy man on his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lazy man buries his hand in the dish. It makes him tired to bring it to his mouth again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lazy man is wiser in his own eyes than seven men who can give a wise answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who passes by and has a part in someone else’s fight is like one who takes a dog by the ears.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like a crazy man who throws pieces of burning wood and arrows of death,
speaker: Narrator

text: so is the man who fools his neighbor with a lie, and says, “I was only joking.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When there is no wood, the fire goes out. Where there is no one telling secret stories about people, arguing stops.
speaker: Narrator

text: An arguing man makes fights worse. He is like coals to burning wood and wood to a fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The words of one who tells secret things about people are like good-tasting bites of food. They go down into the inside parts of the body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Burning lips and a sinful heart are like a pot covered with silver waste.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who hates covers it up with his lips, but stores up false ways in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he speaks with kindness, do not believe him, for there are seven things that are hated in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if his hate is covered with false ways, his sin will be found out in front of the great meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who digs a deep hole will fall into it, and he who rolls a stone will have it return upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: A lying tongue hates those it crushes, and a mouth that speaks false words destroys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not talk much about tomorrow, for you do not know what a day will bring.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let another man praise you, and not your own mouth. Let a stranger, and not your own lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: A stone is heavy, and sand is heavy, but to be made angry by a fool weighs more than both of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anger causes trouble and a bad temper is like a flood, but who can stand when there is jealousy?
speaker: Narrator

text: Sharp words spoken in the open are better than love that is hidden.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pains given by a friend are faithful, but the kisses of one who hates you are false.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who is full hates honey, but any bitter thing is sweet to a hungry man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like a bird that goes away from her nest, so is a man who goes away from his home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Oil and perfume make the heart glad, so are a man’s words sweet to his friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not leave your own friend or your father’s friend alone, and do not go to your brother’s house in the day of your trouble. A neighbor who is near is better than a brother who is far away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be wise, my son, and make my heart glad, so I may answer him who puts me to shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise man sees sin and hides himself, but the fool goes on and suffers for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the man’s coat who has given himself as trust for what a stranger owes. And hold him to his promise who has given it as trust for a sinful woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who praises his neighbor with a loud voice early in the morning will be thought of as saying bad things against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: An arguing woman is like water falling drop by drop on a day it is raining.
speaker: Narrator

text: To try to stop her is like trying to stop the wind, or like trying to catch oil in his right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Iron is made sharp with iron, and one man is made sharp by a friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who cares for the fig tree will eat its fruit, and he who cares for the one he works for will be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: As water acts as a mirror to a face, so the heart of man acts as a mirror to a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: The place of the dead is never filled, and the eyes of man are never filled.
speaker: Narrator

text: The melting-pot is for silver and the fire for gold, and a man is tested by the praise he receives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if you crush a fool in a pot used for crushing grain, his foolish way will not leave him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know well how your flocks are doing, and keep your mind on your cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Riches do not last forever, and a crown does not pass from family to family.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the grass is gone, the new plants are seen, and the plants of the mountains are gathered in.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lambs will be for your clothes, and the goats will bring the price of a field.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be enough goats’ milk for your food, for the food of all your house, and a living for your young women.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sinful run away when no one is trying to catch them, but those who are right with God have as much strength of heart as a lion.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a nation sins, it has many rulers, but with a man of understanding and much learning, it will last a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: A poor man who makes it hard for the poor is like a heavy rain which leaves no food.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who turn away from the law praise the sinful, but those who keep the law fight against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sinful men do not understand what is right and fair, but those who look to the Lord understand all things.
speaker: Narrator

text: A poor man who walks in his honor is better than a rich man who is sinful in his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who keeps the law is a wise son, but a friend of men who eat too much puts his father to shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who gets money by being paid much for the use of it, gathers it for him who will be kind to the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who turns his ear away from listening to the law, even his prayer is a hated thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who leads good people into a sinful way will fall into his own deep hole, but good will come to those without blame.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rich man is wise in his own eyes, but the poor man who has understanding sees through him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When those who are right with God win, there is great honor, but when the sinful rule, men hide themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will not go well for the man who hides his sins, but he who tells his sins and turns from them will be given loving-pity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Happy is the man who always fears the Lord, but he who makes his heart hard will fall into trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: A sinful ruler over poor people is like a lion making noise or a bear running to fight.
speaker: Narrator

text: A ruler who takes much from the people who have little does not have understanding. But he who hates wanting something that belongs to someone else will live a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who is loaded down with the guilt of human blood will run in fear until death. Let no one help him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who walks without blame will be kept safe, but he who is sinful will fall all at once.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who works his land will have more than enough food, but he who wastes his time will become very poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: A faithful man will have many good things, but he who hurries to be rich will be punished for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: To show favor is not good, because a man will sin for a piece of bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man with a sinful eye hurries to be rich. He does not know that he will be in need.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who speaks strong words to a man will later find more favor than he who gives false respect with his tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who robs his father or his mother, and says, “It is not a sin,” is the friend of a man who destroys.
speaker: Narrator

text: A proud man starts fights, but all will go well for the man who trusts in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who trusts in his own heart is a fool, but he who walks in wisdom will be kept safe.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who gives to the poor will never want, but many bad things will happen to the man who shuts his eyes to the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sinful rule, men hide themselves, but when they pass away, those who do what is right become many.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who does not listen after many strong words are spoken to him will be destroyed all at once and without help.
speaker: Narrator

text: When those who are right with God rule, the people are glad, but when a sinful man rules, the people have sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who loves wisdom makes his father glad, but he who goes with women who sell the use of their bodies wastes his money.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king makes the land strong by doing what is right and fair, but the one who takes pay for doing wrong, destroys it.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who gives his neighbor sweet-sounding words that are not true spreads a net for his own feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: A sinful man is trapped by his sins, but a man who is right with God sings for joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who is right with God cares about the rights of poor people, but the sinful man does not understand such things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Men who speak against others set a city on fire, but wise men turn away anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a wise man argues with a foolish man, the fool only gets angry or laughs, and there is no peace and quiet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Men who kill hate him without blame, but a good man cares for his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: A fool always loses his temper, but a wise man keeps quiet.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a ruler listens to lies, all who work for him will become sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord gives light to the eyes of both the poor man and the man who makes it hard for others.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the king is fair as he judges the poor, his throne will stand forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: The stick and strong words give wisdom, but a child who gets his own way brings shame to his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sinful are many, sins become many, but those who are right with God will see their fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: Punish your son when he does wrong and he will give you comfort. Yes, he will give joy to your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where there is no understanding of the Word of the Lord, the people do whatever they want to, but happy is he who keeps the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: A servant will not be taught by words alone. For even if he understands, he will not answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you see a man who is quick with his words? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who gives good care to his servant from the time he is young, will in the end find him to be a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man of anger starts fights, and a man with a bad temper is full of wrong-doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man’s pride will bring him down, but he whose spirit is without pride will receive honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who works with a robber hates his own life. He knows about the bad that will come, but can tell nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fear of man brings a trap, but he who trusts in the Lord will be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many look for the ruler’s favor, but what is right and fair comes from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: A sinful man is a shame to those who are right with God, and he who is right with God is a shame to the sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: The words of Agur the son of Jakeh of Massa. The man says to Ithiel and Ucal:
speaker: Narrator

text: For sure, I am more foolish than any man, and I do not have the understanding of a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have not learned wisdom, and I do not know much about the Holy One.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who has gone up into heaven and come down? Who has gathered the wind in His hands? Who has gathered the waters in His coat? Who has put in place all the ends of the earth? What is His name, and what is His Son’s name? For sure you know!
speaker: Narrator

text: Every word of God has been proven true. He is a safe-covering to those who trust in Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not add to His words, or He will speak strong words to you and prove you to be a liar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two things I have asked of You. Do not keep me from having them before I die:
speaker: Narrator

text: Take lies and what is false far from me. Do not let me be poor or rich. Feed me with the food that I need.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will not be afraid that I will be full and turn my back against You and say, “Who is the Lord?” And I will not be afraid that I will be poor and steal, and bring shame on the name of my God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not speak against a slave while talking with his owner, or he may curse you and you will be found guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are those who curse their fathers, and do not honor their mothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are people who are pure in their own eyes, but are not washed from their own dirt.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a kind, O, how proud are his eyes! His eyes are opened wide with pride.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a kind of man whose teeth are swords, whose jaws are like knives, who eat up those who are suffering from the earth, and those in need from among men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who lives by the blood of another has two daughters, “Give,” “Give.” There are three things that are never filled, four that never say, “Enough”:
speaker: Narrator

text: The place of the dead, the woman who cannot have children, the earth that is always thirsty for water, and fire that never says, “Enough.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The eye that makes fun of a father and hates to obey a mother will be picked out by the ravens of the valley and eaten by the young eagles.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are three things which are too great for me, four which I do not understand:
speaker: Narrator

text: The way of an eagle in the sky, the way of a snake on a rock, the way of a ship out at sea, and the way of a man with a woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the way of a woman who is not faithful in marriage: She eats and washes her mouth, and says, “I have done no wrong.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Under three things the earth shakes, and under four it cannot stand:
speaker: Narrator

text: Under a servant when he becomes king, under a fool when he is filled with food,
speaker: Narrator

text: under a woman who is not loved when she gets a husband, and under a woman servant when she takes the place of the woman of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are four things that are small on the earth, but they are very wise:
speaker: Narrator

text: The ants are not a strong people, but they store up their food in the summer.
speaker: Narrator

text: The badgers are not a strong people, but they make their houses in the rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: The locusts have no king, but they go as an army.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can take the lizard in your hands, but it is found in kings’ houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are three things which have honor in their steps, even four which show honor in their walk:
speaker: Narrator

text: The lion, which is powerful among wild animals and does not turn away from any,
speaker: Narrator

text: the proud rooster, the male goat, and a king when his army is with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you have been foolish in honoring yourself, or if you have planned wrong-doing, put your hand on your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaking milk makes butter, and hitting the nose brings blood. So fighting comes because of anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: The words of Lemuel king of Massa, which his mother taught him:
speaker: Narrator

text: What, my son? What, son who came from within me? What, son of my promises?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not give your strength to women, or your ways to that which destroys kings.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not for kings, O Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine, or for rulers to desire strong drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or they might drink and forget the law, and go against the rights of all who are suffering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give strong drink to him who is about to die, and wine to him whose life is full of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let him drink and forget how poor he is, and remember his trouble no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: Open your mouth for those who cannot speak, and for the rights of those who are left without help.
speaker: Narrator

text: Open your mouth. Be right and fair in what you decide. Stand up for the rights of those who are suffering and in need.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who can find a good wife? For she is worth far more than rubies that make one rich.
speaker: Narrator

text: The heart of her husband trusts in her, and he will never stop getting good things.
speaker: Narrator

text: She does him good and not bad all the days of her life.
speaker: Narrator

text: She looks for wool and flax, and works with willing hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: She is like ships that trade. She brings her food from far away.
speaker: Narrator

text: She rises while it is still night and makes food for all those in her house. She gives work for the young women to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: She gives careful thought to a field and buys it. She plants grape-vines from what she has earned.
speaker: Narrator

text: She makes herself ready with strength, and makes her arms strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: She sees that what she has earned is good. Her lamp does not go out at night.
speaker: Narrator

text: She puts her hands to the wheel to make cloth.
speaker: Narrator

text: She opens her hand to the poor, and holds out her hands to those in need.
speaker: Narrator

text: She is not afraid of the snow for those in her house, for all of them are dressed in red.
speaker: Narrator

text: She makes coverings for herself. Her clothes are linen cloth and purple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her husband is known in the gates, when he sits among the leaders of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: She makes linen clothes and sells them. She brings belts to those who trade.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her clothes are strength and honor. She is full of joy about the future.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She
opens her mouth with wisdom. The teaching of kindness is on her tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text: She looks well to the ways of those in her house, and does not eat the bread of doing nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her children rise up and honor her. Her husband does also, and he praises her, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Many daughters have done well, but you have done better than all of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pleasing ways lie and beauty comes to nothing, but a woman who fears the Lord will be praised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give her the fruit of her hands, and let her works praise her in the gates.
speaker: Narrator
